title: The Story of My Life; Recollections and Reflections
author: Terry, Ellen
snippet: To speak by the certificate, I was born on the 27th of February, 1848,at Coventry. Many years afterwards, when people were kind enough tothink that the house in which I was born deserved to be discovered,there was a dispute as to which house in Market Street could claim me. The dispute was left unsettled in rather a curious way.

title: The Story of My Life; Recollections and Reflections

title: A holiday tour in Europe.
author: Cook, Joel
snippet: Berne thus publicly recognizes the virtue of cleanliness, and also runs down the centre of its chief street a great sunken gutter for the especial drainage of these fountains and tubs, over which sundry bears, knights, and curious statues are set as guardian augels. This is called in one portion Market Street, and it would be a novel sight in Philadelphia to see on our Market Street all the city's washerwomen (including the Chinese)  distributed at their tubs along the middle of the street, talking scandal and beating a tattoo on their washclothes. This is one of the sights of Berne.

title: Europe from May to December,
author: Williams, Rudolph.
snippet: Yet Cork is not all Corn Market Street, and Corn Market Street is not all of Cork. There are some Mice streets and some nice buildings, but it is a dirty city.

title: Europe from May to December,
author: Williams, Rudolph.
snippet: V\'^e walked through Corn Market Street, a street devoted to the market. In the street, all over the roadway, were piles of old clothes, old furniture, crates of chickens, hobbled geese, anchored  goats and hungry dogs.

title: Weir of Hermiston :
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: It chanced one day, as he was strolling down Market Street on the eve of his fortnight's holiday,  that his eye was caught by certain railway bills, and in very idleness of mind he calculated that he might be home for Christmas if he started on the morrow. The fancy thrilled him with desire,  and in one moment he decided he would go.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: One morning, about a week after their re-turn to town, NeUy was despatched by her mis-tress on an errand to Stockbridge market. She had accomplished it, and was preparing toascend the steps which lead into Market Streeton her return, when, to her delight and asto-nishment she recognised in a servant girlabout to descend them, her old friend, Janet. Not the Janet of Winstraelea, however, the duUslatternly drudge of Mr. and Mrs. McMurdo'sestablishment—but smartened, tidied, andgreatly improved in consequence.

title: The Ossians
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: A cold wind blew down Market Street as they stood in silence. After a moment Hannah spoke with a surprisingly cheery tone.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: On the plains of Nebraska, in the mountains of Wyoming, it was still the same cry, and dismal to my heart, " Come back ! " That was what we heard by the way " about the good country  we were going to." And at that very hour the Sand-lot of San Francisco was crowded with the unemployed, and the echo from the other side of Market Street was repeating the rant of demagogues.
